title: 111_hr1836
content: The "Payroll Tax Holiday Act of 2009" allows for a payroll tax holiday for small businesses during a portion of 2009. During the payroll tax holiday period in 2009, eligible small businesses will have zero payroll taxes imposed on remuneration. Self-employment taxes for eligible small businesses will also be reduced based on the income during the holiday period. During the payroll tax holiday period in 2009, eligible small businesses will have zero payroll taxes imposed on remuneration. Self-employment taxes for eligible small businesses will also be reduced based on the income during the holiday period. The compensation of the taxpayer subject to tax under section 3211(a) for the taxable year shall be reduced by the payroll tax holiday period income for purposes of applying the tax rate determined by reference to the taxes imposed by sections 3101(a) and 3111(a). The payroll tax holiday period income is calculated as a percentage of self-employment income or compensation subject to tax under section 3211(a) for the taxable year. During the payroll tax holiday period, eligible small businesses with up to 50 employees will have zero payroll taxes imposed on remuneration. The applicable percentage for the holiday period is calculated by dividing the number of days within the holiday period by the total number of days in the taxable year. During the payroll tax holiday period, all persons treated as a single employer under specific sections will be considered one taxpayer, and temporary lay-offs will be disregarded. The holiday period extends from the enactment date of the section until January 1, 2010. There is a limitation on the reduction in employer taxes at the end of the holiday period. During the payroll tax holiday period, if the increase in employer taxes exceeds the aggregate increase in employee compensation or capital expenditures, the applicable employer tax for the first payroll period after the holiday period will be increased by the excess. Employer taxes include taxes imposed by specific sections. During the payroll tax holiday period, the Secretary will notify small business employers of the payroll tax holiday period in any manner deemed appropriate. Conforming amendments are made to the table of sections for subchapter C. Sec. 3128 of the Internal Revenue Code of 1986 introduces a payroll tax holiday for small businesses in 2009. The amendments apply to remuneration paid after the enactment of the Act, with specific provisions for self-employment taxes. The Secretary will inform small business employers of the payroll tax holiday period, and conforming amendments are made to the table of sections for subchapter C.
